vitalik.eth on Twitter

‚ÄúYYYY-MM-DD is the only correct date format. * It‚Äôs an ISO standard: https://t.co/n3wKGrNuMH * It‚Äôs unambiguous (is 03/05/22 March 5 or May 3? item.title: Book review: "Slouching Toward Utopia"
item.description:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs beautiful‚Ä¶even if it‚Äôs where everybody died.‚Äù ‚Äî Nakagawa Noriko This may actually be the first book review I‚Äôve done before a book has actually been released! Fortunately, I was able to secure an advance copy of the book from my podcast co-host, Brad DeLong. The book comes out September 6th, so hopefully this review can tide you over until then‚Ä¶

item.title: The News: We Can See Clearly Now
item.description:
Putting aside the usual woes, which are as woeful as ever this week, let‚Äôs just take a moment to talk about what the Webb telescope is going to do for us, and why scientific investigation of the universe is such a happy and soothing thing for many of us‚Ä¶

URL: https://timothyburke.substack.com/p/the-news-we-can-see-clearly-now?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Well, Well, Well: Today Is a Very Good Day for the Book Slouching Towards Utopia

item.title: No Housing Please, We're a Community
item.description:
I received a really interesting, insightful comment on a subscribers-only piece from a few weeks ago, on the tension between community and continuity on the one hand, and development and growth on the other. I had mentioned in passing the right-wing meme ‚ÄúI will not live in a pod,‚Äù which refers to the supposed notion that liberals want to cram everyone i‚Ä¶

URL: https://thedeletedscenes.substack.com/p/no-housing-thank-you-were-a-community?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Well, Well, Well: Today Is a Very Good Day for the Book Slouching Towards Utopia

item.title: Strategies of Unusual Size
item.description:
May 6, 2022 I wrapped the 2022 edition of my undergraduate ‚ÄúGrand Strategy‚Äù seminar this past Tuesday. I like teaching the class. I really do. But I have significant reservations about ‚Äúgrand strategy‚Äù as a classroom subject. I‚Äôm not at all convinced that‚Ä¶

item.title: The rule of nihilists
item.description:
A friend sent me recently an abbreviated version of Xi Jinping‚Äôs January 2013 speech to the members of the Central Committee of CPC (the English translation is here). The speech is often mentioned, generally in the context of greater ideological control and ‚Äúauthoritarian tendencies‚Äù of Xi Jinping, but I have not read it until I got it from him‚Ä¶

URL: https://branko2f7.substack.com/p/the-rule-of-nihilists?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

item.title: The Debatable Land #24: Things Fall Apart
item.description:
An unbecoming end A resignation speech is an easy one to give. Even those folk mightily pleased to see you gone are willing to make some allowances for the circumstances in which the resignation address is given. The requirements for a successful farewell are not exacting: show some humility, a little knowing humour, a nod to history and the great responsibilities of office, and, perhaps above all, depart with a certain stoic grace‚Ä¶

URL: https://alexmassie.substack.com/p/the-debatable-land-24-things-fall?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

item.title: The Three Definitions of "Science"
item.description:
Several years ago now, I wrote a book about the universality of science, Eureka: Discovering Your Inner Scientist, which I‚Äôm still really proud of, but which was a commercial bomb. I spent a good deal of time around its release talking about the nature of science, and how scientific thinking turns up in all manner of a‚Ä¶

Phillips P. OBrien on Twitter
